Calculate the average rate of reaction for calcium oxide in mol·s−1mol·s−1.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to three decimal places.
Answer: mol·s−1mol·s−1

    Answer: minmin

  2. Which of the following reasons explain why the reaction slows over time?

    A The products are removed from the reaction which slows the rate of the reaction.
    B The reaction gets tired which leads to a slower rate of reaction.
    C There is a lower concentration of reactants which leads to a slower reaction rate.

Changes in reaction rates

Adapted from DBE Nov 2015 Grade 12, P2, Q5
Physical constants ·· Chemistry formulas ·· Periodic table ·· Standard reduction potentials

Dilute acids, indicated in the table below, react with excess zinc in each of the three experiments to produce hydrogen gas. The zinc is completely covered with the acid in each experiment.

Exp.Dilute acid
1 60 cm360 cm3 of 0,3 mol·dm−30,3 mol·dm−3 H2SO4
2 30 cm330 cm3 of 0,6 mol·dm−30,6 mol·dm−3 HNO3
3 60 cm360 cm3 of 0,3 mol·dm−30,3 mol·dm−3 HNO3

The initial mass of zinc used in each experiment is 1,8 g1,8 g. The balanced equation for the reaction in Experiment 3 is:

Zn(s)++2HNO3(aq) →→ Zn(NO3)2(aq)++H2(g)

  1. Calculate the mass of zinc present in the flask after completion of the reaction in Experiment 3.
  2. How will the mass of zinc present in the flask after completion of the reaction in Experiment 2 compare to the answer to the previous question?
INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer:
  1. The mass of zinc present after Experiment 3 is .
  2. The mass of zinc present after Experiment 2 is the mass present after Experiment 3.
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.01))

The acid is in excess.

Consider the following statements regarding these two reactions:

I The initial rate at which the acid is used up in test tube R is greater than the initial rate at which the acid is used up in test tube S.
II After completion of the reactions, the moles of acid that remain in test tube R will be greater than that in test tube S.
III The amount of hydrogen gas formed in test tube R is equal to the amount of hydrogen gas formed in test tube S.

Which of the above statements is/are true?

A I only
B II only
C III only
D I and III only
